title: 1 Peter Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Peter chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Peter Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Peter Chapter 2.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:1, what should believers lay aside?
options: Malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings
Pride and arrogance
Doubt and fear
Greed and selfishness
questions.correctAnswer: Malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:1 instructs believers to lay aside all malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 2:2, believers are compared to what kind of babes?
options: Newborn babes
Strong infants
Weaned children
Old men
questions.correctAnswer: Newborn babes
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:2 compares believers to newborn babes who desire the sincere milk of the word.

questions.question: What is the 'living stone' referred to in 1 Peter 2:4?
options: The Lord
Jesus Christ
God
A stone chosen of God and precious
questions.correctAnswer: A stone chosen of God and precious
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:4 speaks of Jesus as the living stone, disallowed of men but chosen of God and precious.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:5, believers are built up as what?
options: A spiritual house and holy priesthood
A mighty fortress
A great nation
A holy temple
questions.correctAnswer: A spiritual house and holy priesthood
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:5 explains believers are built up as a spiritual house and a holy priesthood.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 2:6, what is laid in Sion?
options: A chief corner stone
The Ark of the Covenant
A golden altar
A pillar of fire
questions.correctAnswer: A chief corner stone
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:6 quotes scripture saying a chief corner stone is laid in Sion.

questions.question: Who is the stone of stumbling according to 1 Peter 2:8?
options: Christ
Moses
David
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:8 states Christ is the stone of stumbling and rock of offence to disobedient people.

questions.question: What kind of people are believers described as in 1 Peter 2:9?
options: A chosen generation, royal priesthood, holy nation
A humble congregation
A wandering tribe
A secret society
questions.correctAnswer: A chosen generation, royal priesthood, holy nation
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:9 calls believers a chosen generation, royal priesthood, and holy nation.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:10, what have believers now obtained?
options: Mercy
Wealth
Power
Knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:10 explains believers who were not a people have now obtained mercy.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 2:11 urge believers to abstain from?
options: Fleshly lusts
Bad company
Idle talk
Pride
questions.correctAnswer: Fleshly lusts
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:11 urges believers to abstain from fleshly lusts which war against the soul.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:13, to whom should believers submit themselves?
options: Every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake
Only to God
Only to their families
To no one
questions.correctAnswer: Every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:13 instructs believers to submit to every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Peter 2:17 tells believers to fear God and honor the king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:17 commands believers to fear God and honor the king.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Peter 2:22 states that Christ committed sin.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:22 says Christ did no sin and no guile was found in His mouth.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Peter 2:25 compares believers to sheep going astray who now have returned to the Shepherd.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:25 compares believers to sheep that were going astray but have now returned to the Shepherd and Bishop of their souls.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Peter 2:24: 'Who his own self bare our _____ in his own body on the tree.'
options: sins
burdens
troubles
fears
questions.correctAnswer: sins
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:24 states that Christ bore our sins in His own body on the tree.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 2:20 say is acceptable with God?
options: Patient suffering when doing well
Immediate reward for good deeds
Revenge against wrongdoers
Ignoring suffering
questions.correctAnswer: Patient suffering when doing well
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:20 teaches that patiently enduring suffering when doing well is acceptable with God.

medium.title: 1 Peter Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Peter Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 2 teach us to deal with harmful attitudes such as malice and envy in practical Christian living?
options: Lay aside all malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings
Ignore others and focus only on your own growth
Engage in debates to prove your point
Accept that these attitudes are natural and unavoidable
questions.correctAnswer: Lay aside all malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:1 instructs believers to put away harmful attitudes like malice and envy as a foundation for spiritual growth and healthy relationships. This is supported by verses 1 Peter 2:11 and 1 Peter 2:12 emphasizing holy living and good conduct among others.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2, what should new believers desire in order to grow spiritually?
options: The sincere milk of the word
Material blessings and success
Power over others
Freedom from all responsibilities
questions.correctAnswer: The sincere milk of the word
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:2 compares new believers to newborn babes who should desire the sincere milk of the word in order to grow, emphasizing the importance of nourishment through Scripture. This is connected with spiritual growth and maturity.

questions.question: What metaphor does 1 Peter 2 use to describe Christ and believers’ role in God’s spiritual house?
options: Living stones built into a spiritual house
Shepherds leading sheep
Branches on a vine
Light shining in darkness
questions.correctAnswer: Living stones built into a spiritual house
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:4-5 uses the metaphor of Christ as the living stone and believers as living stones built up into a spiritual house, highlighting the unity and purpose of believers as a holy priesthood offering spiritual sacrifices.

questions.question: How should Christians respond to authority figures according to 1 Peter 2?
options: Submit to every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake
Only obey when it benefits them
Challenge authority openly
Ignore government rules
questions.correctAnswer: Submit to every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:13-14 teaches believers to submit to authorities because they are appointed for punishment of evildoers and praise of those who do well, encouraging respectful obedience as an expression of faith.

questions.question: What is the purpose of doing good works among the Gentiles, as stated in 1 Peter 2?
options: That they may glorify God in the day of visitation
To gain popularity
To avoid persecution
To receive material rewards
questions.correctAnswer: That they may glorify God in the day of visitation
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:12 explains that good conduct among the Gentiles serves as a testimony so that even if accused of wrongdoing, their good works may lead others to glorify God when He visits.

questions.question: What attitude should servants have toward their masters according to 1 Peter 2?
options: Be subject to their masters with all fear, even if they are harsh
Only obey if the masters are kind
Rebel against unfair treatment
Avoid their masters when possible
questions.correctAnswer: Be subject to their masters with all fear, even if they are harsh
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:18 teaches servants to obey their masters with respect and fear, not only those who are kind but also the difficult ones, showing submission as an act of conscience toward God.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 2 instruct believers to use their freedom in Christ?
options: Not as a cloak for maliciousness but as servants of God
To pursue personal desires without restraint
To judge others freely
To reject all authority
questions.correctAnswer: Not as a cloak for maliciousness but as servants of God
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:16 warns believers to exercise their freedom responsibly, avoiding misuse as a cover for evil but living as devoted servants of God.

questions.question: What is the significance of Christ’s suffering as taught in 1 Peter 2 for believers facing trials?
options: Christ suffered for us as an example to follow in patience and righteousness
Suffering is a sign of God’s rejection
Believers should avoid suffering at all costs
Only suffering for faults is acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Christ suffered for us as an example to follow in patience and righteousness
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:21-23 shows that Christ’s patient suffering without sin or retaliation is a model for believers enduring wrongful suffering, encouraging perseverance and trust in God’s righteous judgment.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2, what spiritual identity do believers have that compels them to praise God?
options: A chosen generation, royal priesthood, holy nation, peculiar people
A worldly nation with many faults
A group seeking power and influence
A people bound by law only
questions.correctAnswer: A chosen generation, royal priesthood, holy nation, peculiar people
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:9 describes believers as a chosen generation and royal priesthood called to proclaim God’s praises who brought them from darkness into marvelous light, highlighting their unique identity and purpose.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 2 teach about how to handle suffering when it is undeserved?
options: It is thankworthy to endure grief for conscience toward God
Sufferings should be avoided at all costs
Retaliate against those who cause suffering
Suffering is meaningless and should be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: It is thankworthy to endure grief for conscience toward God
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:19 emphasizes that enduring suffering wrongfully for the sake of conscience toward God is commendable, encouraging believers to maintain integrity under trial.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 2 describe the transformation of believers from their previous state?
options: They were not a people but now are the people of God and have obtained mercy
They remain outsiders with no special identity
They are chosen based on their good works
They must earn mercy through obedience
questions.correctAnswer: They were not a people but now are the people of God and have obtained mercy
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:10 highlights the spiritual transformation where believers who were once not considered God’s people have now received mercy and belong to Him, underscoring God’s grace.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Peter 2 teaches that believers should only honor the king if he is good and just.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:17 commands believers to honor all men, love the brotherhood, fear God, and honor the king, without conditions on the king’s character.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Peter 2, Christians are called to abstain from fleshly lusts because they war against the soul.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:11 instructs believers to abstain from fleshly lusts as these desires battle against the soul, indicating the importance of self-control and holiness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 1 Peter 2:24 says, "Who his own self bare our sins in his own body on the _______, that we, being dead to sins, should live unto righteousness."
options: tree
cross
mountain
altar
questions.correctAnswer: tree
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:24 uses 'tree' to refer to the cross on which Christ bore our sins, enabling believers to live righteously, highlighting the sacrificial nature of Christ’s death.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 2 advise believers to respond when they are falsely accused or slandered?
options: Maintain honest conduct so that good works silence ignorance
Defend themselves aggressively
Ignore the accusations completely
Seek revenge when possible
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain honest conduct so that good works silence ignorance
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:12 and 2:15 teach believers to live honorably and do good so that their good deeds silence foolish accusations and glorify God, promoting a peaceful and godly witness.

hard.title: 1 Peter Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Peter Chapter 2.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 2:4-5, believers are compared to 'living stones' built up as a spiritual house. Which Old Testament concept does this imagery most directly echo?
options: The Temple in Jerusalem
The Tower of Babel
Solomon's Palace
The Ark of the Covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The Temple in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The metaphor of believers as 'living stones' built into a spiritual house reflects the Old Testament concept of the Temple, which was constructed from stones and served as a holy dwelling place for God (1 Peter 2:4-5).

questions.question: What is the significance of Christ being described as the 'chief corner stone' in 1 Peter 2:6, and how does this relate to Isaiah 28:16?
options: It signifies Christ as the foundation of the church, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy of a chosen, precious stone.
It refers to Christ as a builder of physical houses.
It symbolizes Christ as a stone used for sacrifices.
It implies Christ was rejected by God.
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies Christ as the foundation of the church, fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy of a chosen, precious stone.
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:6 quotes Isaiah 28:16, presenting Christ as the cornerstone chosen and precious, foundational for God's spiritual house and people.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:9, what four identities are attributed to believers, and what is their purpose?
options: Chosen generation, royal priesthood, holy nation, peculiar people; to proclaim God's praises.
Faithful servants, holy disciples, chosen tribe, royal lineage; to rule nations.
Covenant people, holy congregation, royal family, chosen flock; to gain earthly riches.
Saints, angels, prophets, kings; to conquer enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: Chosen generation, royal priesthood, holy nation, peculiar people; to proclaim God's praises.
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:9 describes believers with these identities to highlight their calling to proclaim the praises of God who called them out of darkness into light.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'desire the sincere milk of the word' in 1 Peter 2:2 metaphorically imply about the believers’ spiritual growth?
options: Believers should crave pure teaching to grow spiritually like newborn babies.
Believers should drink literal milk for strength.
Believers are called to abstain from the word.
Believers must avoid mature teaching.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should crave pure teaching to grow spiritually like newborn babies.
questions.explanation: The phrase in 1 Peter 2:2 uses the metaphor of newborn babes craving milk to emphasize the need for pure, foundational teaching for spiritual growth.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 2:11, believers are exhorted as 'strangers and pilgrims' to abstain from what, and what is the significance of this metaphor in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Fleshly lusts; it underscores their temporary status on earth and spiritual journey.
Food and drink; it symbolizes fasting.
Evil rulers; it signifies political exile.
Material possessions; it indicates poverty.
questions.correctAnswer: Fleshly lusts; it underscores their temporary status on earth and spiritual journey.
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:11 uses the pilgrimage metaphor common in the ancient Near East to highlight believers’ transient life on earth and the need to avoid sinful desires.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 2:13-14 instruct believers to relate to human authorities, and what is the theological rationale behind this?
options: Submit to every ordinance for the Lord's sake; authorities are instituted by God.
Rebel against unjust rulers immediately; self-defense is paramount.
Ignore human laws; only God's law matters.
Only obey good rulers; resist oppressive ones.
questions.correctAnswer: Submit to every ordinance for the Lord's sake; authorities are instituted by God.
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 teach submission to human authorities because they serve God's purpose for order and justice, reflecting God’s sovereignty over earthly powers.

questions.question: What Greek word translated as 'guile' in 1 Peter 2:1 refers to deceitfulness or cunning, and how does its rejection shape the ethical mandate of the passage?
options: Dolos; believers must reject deceit to live honestly.
Agape; believers must love genuinely.
Pistis; believers must maintain faith.
Charis; believers must show grace.
questions.correctAnswer: Dolos; believers must reject deceit to live honestly.
questions.explanation: The Greek word 'dolos' means deceit or cunning; rejecting it (1 Peter 2:1) calls believers to a life of sincerity and honesty.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Peter 2:24, Christ's suffering on the tree was to bear our sins so that we might live righteously.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:24 explicitly states that Christ bore our sins in his body on the tree so that we might live unto righteousness.

questions.question: What is the role of 'spiritual sacrifices' mentioned in 1 Peter 2:5, and how does this concept connect with the Old Testament priesthood?
options: Offerings acceptable to God through Jesus Christ; believers now serve as a holy priesthood.
Animal sacrifices only; continuation of Mosaic Law.
Monetary offerings; financial support of the temple.
Physical labor; rebuilding the temple.
questions.correctAnswer: Offerings acceptable to God through Jesus Christ; believers now serve as a holy priesthood.
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:5 describes believers as a holy priesthood offering spiritual sacrifices through Christ, fulfilling and transforming the Old Testament priestly role.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:17, which four groups or principles are believers instructed to honor or fear, reflecting the social and religious order of the time?
options: All men, brotherhood, God, king.
Only rulers, priests, prophets, saints.
Family, neighbors, strangers, enemies.
Wealth, wisdom, youth, elders.
questions.correctAnswer: All men, brotherhood, God, king.
questions.explanation: The verse calls believers to honor all people, love fellow believers, fear God, and honor the king, reflecting respect for societal and divine authority.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 2:20, why is it considered more honorable to endure suffering for doing good than for doing wrong, and what does this reveal about early Christian ethics?
options: Because patient endurance in righteousness is acceptable to God and reflects Christ’s example.
Because suffering is never honorable.
Because only suffering for faults is praised.
Because patience is irrelevant in faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Because patient endurance in righteousness is acceptable to God and reflects Christ’s example.
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts suffering for faults with suffering for doing good, highlighting the Christian call to imitate Christ by enduring unjust suffering.

questions.question: The phrase 'stone of stumbling and rock of offence' in 1 Peter 2:8 alludes to which Old Testament prophecy and what does it reveal about Christ's reception by some people?
options: Isaiah 8:14; Christ is a cause of rejection and offense to the disobedient.
Psalm 23; Christ is a shepherd.
Genesis 1; Christ is the creator.
Exodus 20; Christ gives commandments.
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah 8:14; Christ is a cause of rejection and offense to the disobedient.
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:8 draws from Isaiah 8:14 portraying Christ as a stumbling block to those who reject him, fulfilling prophecy about the Messiah's reception.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:25, what metaphor describes believers' former and current spiritual condition, and which Old Testament imagery does it recall?
options: Sheep going astray now returned to the Shepherd; recalling Psalm 23.
Lost coins found; recalling the parable in Luke.
Burning bush; recalling Exodus.
Manna in the wilderness; recalling Numbers.
questions.correctAnswer: Sheep going astray now returned to the Shepherd; recalling Psalm 23.
questions.explanation: The metaphor of sheep going astray and returning to the Shepherd recalls Psalm 23's imagery of God's care for His flock.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Peter 2:18 instructs servants to obey only kind masters and to resist harsh ones.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:18 commands servants to submit to all masters, both good and harsh, with respect and fear.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 2:23, how does Christ respond to reviling and suffering, and what does this teach about Christian behavior under persecution?
options: He did not retaliate but entrusted Himself to God’s righteous judgement.
He retaliated with equal force.
He fled from suffering.
He ignored the situation.
questions.correctAnswer: He did not retaliate but entrusted Himself to God’s righteous judgement.
questions.explanation: Verse 23 highlights Christ's non-retaliatory response to injustice, teaching believers to trust God rather than seek revenge.

theological.title: 1 Peter Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Peter Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2, what should believers lay aside in order to grow spiritually?
options: Malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings
Pride, anger, jealousy, greed, and laziness
Doubt, fear, confusion, despair, and ignorance
Hatred, bitterness, slander, gossip, and selfishness
questions.correctAnswer: Malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:1 instructs believers to lay aside malice, guile, hypocrisies, envies, and evil speakings as foundational for spiritual growth. This echoes Ephesians 4:31, Colossians 3:8, James 1:21, Proverbs 4:24, and Hebrews 12:1 which also call for putting away sinful attitudes and behaviors.

questions.question: What metaphor does Peter use in 1 Peter 2 to describe believers' desire for God's word?
options: Newborn babes desiring the sincere milk of the word
Strong warriors thirsting for the sword of the Spirit
Mature trees rooted deeply in the soil of truth
Builders seeking the foundation stone of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Newborn babes desiring the sincere milk of the word
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:2 compares believers to newborn infants who long for the pure spiritual milk of the word so that they may grow. This metaphor aligns with 1 Corinthians 3:2, Hebrews 5:12-14, and John 1:16 where growth in spiritual maturity is nurtured by God's word.

questions.question: Who is described as the 'living stone' disallowed by men but chosen and precious to God?
options: Jesus Christ
Moses
King David
John the Baptist
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:4 identifies the 'living stone' as Jesus Christ, rejected by men but chosen and precious to God. This is consistent with Isaiah 28:16, Psalm 118:22, Matthew 21:42, and Romans 9:33 where Christ is the cornerstone rejected by builders.

questions.question: How does Peter describe believers in 1 Peter 2:5?
options: As lively stones built up a spiritual house and a holy priesthood
As wandering sheep needing a shepherd
As soldiers fighting against spiritual forces
As branches grafted into the vine
questions.correctAnswer: As lively stones built up a spiritual house and a holy priesthood
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:5 calls believers 'lively stones' being built into a spiritual house and a holy priesthood to offer spiritual sacrifices. This echoes Exodus 19:6, Hebrews 10:21-22, and Revelation 1:6 where the people of God are described as priestly and holy.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'chief corner stone' mentioned in 1 Peter 2:6?
options: It is the foundation of the spiritual house chosen and precious, in whom believers are not confounded
It is the stone that marks the entrance to the temple
It symbolizes the law given to Moses
It represents the altar for sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It is the foundation of the spiritual house chosen and precious, in whom believers are not confounded
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:6 cites scripture about the chief cornerstone laid in Zion, chosen and precious, on which believers place their faith without shame. This aligns with Isaiah 28:16, Psalm 118:22, Ephesians 2:20, and Romans 9:33 where Christ is the foundation of God's people.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:9, what four descriptions does Peter give to believers as a result of being called out of darkness?
options: A chosen generation, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a peculiar people
A holy city, a royal family, a sanctified temple, a devoted tribe
A redeemed people, a faithful church, a sanctified group, a righteous family
A forgiven nation, a holy congregation, a peculiar flock, a chosen flock
questions.correctAnswer: A chosen generation, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a peculiar people
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:9 describes believers as a chosen generation, royal priesthood, holy nation, and peculiar people to proclaim God's praises. This echoes Exodus 19:5-6, Isaiah 43:20-21, and Revelation 1:6 affirming the identity of God's people.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 2:10 say about believers' past condition compared to now?
options: They were not a people but are now the people of God; they had not obtained mercy but now have obtained mercy
They were chosen from the beginning and have always had mercy
They were always a holy nation but lacked knowledge
They were once strangers but now are citizens of the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: They were not a people but are now the people of God; they had not obtained mercy but now have obtained mercy
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:10 contrasts the former state of believers as not being a people and lacking mercy with their new status as God's people who have received mercy. This corresponds with Hosea 1:10, Exodus 6:7, Isaiah 43:20-21, and Romans 9:25-26.

questions.question: What behavior does Peter urge believers to abstain from in 1 Peter 2:11?
options: Fleshly lusts which war against the soul
Worldly ambitions and greed
False doctrines and heresies
Anger and strife among brethren
questions.correctAnswer: Fleshly lusts which war against the soul
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:11 exhorts believers to abstain from fleshly lusts that wage war against the soul. Similar calls can be found in Galatians 5:16-17, James 1:14-15, 1 John 2:16, and Romans 8:5-8 regarding the conflict between flesh and spirit.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 2:13-14, to whom should believers submit for the Lord’s sake?
options: Every human authority, including the king and governors
Only to religious leaders and elders
Only to those who are kind and just
No one; believers are free from earthly authorities
questions.correctAnswer: Every human authority, including the king and governors
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:13-14 commands submission to every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake, specifically mentioning kings and governors as those sent to punish evildoers and praise those who do well. This is consistent with Romans 13:1-7, Titus 3:1, and Proverbs 24:21.

questions.question: What is the purpose of doing well and submitting to authority according to 1 Peter 2:15?
options: To silence the ignorance of foolish men
To gain favor and promotions
To avoid persecution and suffering
To earn salvation and blessings
questions.correctAnswer: To silence the ignorance of foolish men
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:15 states that well doing and submission to authority is God's will so that believers may silence the ignorance of foolish men. This reflects Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 5:16, Titus 2:8, 1 Timothy 2:2, and Romans 12:17-21 about good conduct as a witness.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 2:16, how are believers instructed to use their freedom?
options: Not as a cloak for maliciousness, but as servants of God
To pursue personal desires freely without restraint
To challenge and overthrow unjust authorities
To withdraw from society and avoid all conflicts
questions.correctAnswer: Not as a cloak for maliciousness, but as servants of God
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:16 warns believers to use their freedom responsibly, not as a cover for evil but as servants of God. This aligns with Galatians 5:13, Romans 6:18, John 8:36, and 2 Corinthians 3:17 teaching freedom in Christ is for service, not sin.

questions.question: What four exhortations does Peter give in 1 Peter 2:17?
options: Honour all men, love the brotherhood, fear God, honour the king
Love your enemies, forgive all offenses, pray continually, serve humbly
Be patient in suffering, rejoice in hope, be constant in prayer, be thankful
Speak truth, live peaceably, help the poor, defend the weak
questions.correctAnswer: Honour all men, love the brotherhood, fear God, honour the king
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:17 gives four commands: honour everyone, love the brotherhood, fear God, and honour the king. These mirror Jesus’ teachings in Matthew 22:39-40, 1 Timothy 2:1-2, Romans 13:7, and Leviticus 19:18 about love and respect for others, God, and authority.

questions.question: What attitude should servants have toward their masters according to 1 Peter 2:18?
options: Be subject with all fear, not only to the good and gentle but also to the froward
Only obey masters who are kind and just
Rebel against harsh masters
Serve only to gain earthly rewards
questions.correctAnswer: Be subject with all fear, not only to the good and gentle but also to the froward
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:18 instructs servants to submit to their masters with respect and fear, including those who are harsh or difficult. This reflects Jesus’ example (Matthew 27:12-14), Paul’s teaching in Ephesians 6:5-8, and Colossians 3:22-24 about faithful submission.

questions.question: Why is enduring unjust suffering for conscience toward God considered commendable according to 1 Peter 2:19?
options: Because it reflects Christ’s example and pleases God
Because it guarantees earthly rewards
Because it proves superiority over others
Because it allows one to avoid punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Because it reflects Christ’s example and pleases God
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:19 teaches that enduring suffering wrongfully for conscience toward God is commendable, reflecting Christ’s sufferings and pleasing God. This is consistent with Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 5:10-12, Romans 8:17, Hebrews 12:3-11, and Isaiah 53.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 2:24 say Christ accomplished by bearing sins in His body on the tree?
options: That we might die to sin and live to righteousness; by His stripes we are healed
That we might be freed from all earthly suffering
That we might become kings and priests
That the law might be abolished
questions.correctAnswer: That we might die to sin and live to righteousness; by His stripes we are healed
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:24 declares Christ bore our sins on the cross so that believers die to sin and live to righteousness, and by His wounds we are healed. This aligns with Isaiah 53:4-5, Romans 6:6-11, Galatians 2:20, and 2 Corinthians 5:21.
